Cultural and Linguistic BackgroundEmai is mother tongue for approximately 25,000–35,000 members of the Emai clan
in south central Nigeria. It is spoken in ten villages across roughly 250 square kilo-
meters on the plateau between the Edion and Owan rivers of present-day Edo State.
Located at longitude 6° east of Greenwich Meridian and latitude 7° north of the
equator, this area consists primarily of tree savanna, allowing for bush agriculture
involving the harvesting of yam, maize, cassava, and beans among other crops
(Bradbury 1957). Serving as the principal political village of the Emai is Afuze. Other
villages in the clan are Eteye, Evbiame-New-Site, Evbiame-Old-Site, Ogute, Ojavun-
New-Site, Ojavun-Old-Site, Okpokhunmi, Ovbionwu, and Uanhumi.
     The Emai-speaking region is approximately 120 kilometers north of Benin City
by road. It is connected in the south to Sabongida, the principal village of the relat-
ed Ora clan, in the east to Uzebba, the primary village of the related Iuleha clan, and
in the north to Auchi, the headquarters of the Edoid language Yekhee.
     As for the Emai people, oral tradition makes clear the absence of hereditary
chieftancy, a cultural feature frequent among Edoid peoples of its region. According
to oral tradition (Ogbomo 1994), the ancestor of the Emai people is Ima. He is said to
have fled from the ancient kingdom of Benin in about the 16th Century for commit-
ting murder. Ima and his wife, who also came from Benin, had a son Uzuanbi (Oyai-
bi). Uzuanbi, in turn, had two wives, Odidi and Oron, whose sons founded the Emai
speaking villages. Oral tradition varies at this point. According to one version, the
four sons of Uzuanbi and his wives were Uwuno, Urule, Ivbiame, and Uanhumi,
each of whom founded a village. Their sons, Uzuanbi's grandsons, founded the ten
quarters into which the four villages became divided. According to another version,
the village of Uanhumi is named after the son of one wife and the remaining villages
are related to three sons of a second wife. The sons were Uule, Evbiame and
Ovbionwu, whose names are retained, respectively, by the village sites of Ugbuule,
Evbiame-Old-Site, and Ovbionwu, all of which are located off the main Ora-Auchi
road and tend to be northernmost in their respective village groups. Each of these
villages serves to link the remaining Emai-speaking area. Villages in the Uule group,
from south to north, are: Ojavun-Old-Site, Okpokhumi, Eteye, Uanhumi, Afuze,
Ojavun-New-Site. Ugbuule no longer exists as an occupied village. The Evbiame
group from south to north consists of Evbiame-New-Site, Ogute, and Evbiame-Old-
Site. The Ovbionwu group consists solely of Ovbionwu.
     As a linguistic entity, Emai is completely surrounded by Edoid speech varieties.
Its genetic classification as a distinct linguistic unit within Edoid is of recent origin.
Elugbe (1973) classified it as part of a dialect cluster incorporating adjacent Ora
                                                                          Preface | ix(30,000 speakers) and Iuleha (45,000 speakers); Elugbe (1989) locates this cluster
more specifically within the North Central Branch of Edoid. While a word list sup-
porting a cluster relationship among these dialects was not published, broader clas-
sificatory schemes have accepted the cluster interpretation, e.g. Hansford, Bendor-
Samuel and Stanford (1976), Bendor-Samuel (1989) and Crozier and Blench (1992).
Even Christian missionary activity in the area has never generated word lists, since
neither the Bible nor a church hymnal is available in Emai.
     Linguistic investigation of individual languages within the Edoid group is ex-
tremely limited. Other than Emai, no descriptive grammatical treatment, encom-
passing reference grammar, lexicon, and texts, has appeared for a single member of
the 25 or more Edoid languages. Perhaps the most widely recognized comparative
and historical analysis of the Edoid group is Elugbe's (1973) unpublished disserta-
tion “A Comparative Edo Phonology” and its successor, Comparative Edoid: Phonol-
ogy and Lexicon (Elugbe 1989). Also showing an exclusive interest in phonological
matters is Elimelech's (1979) A Tonal Grammar of Etsako, which examines the role of
pitch differences in words and short phrases among dialects of Yekhee spoken
northeast of Emai country.
     Among other Edoid studies, Thomas (1910) presents a highly schematic gram-
matical and lexical analysis of Bini, the numerically and culturally dominant lan-
guage of the group since establishment of the influential Edo Kingdom in the 13th
Century (Ryder 1969). Later studies of Bini amplify portions of this initial analysis.
Melzian (1937) is a descriptive dictionary from which one can infer grammatical
information at the level of parts of speech, while Amayo (1976) and Wescott (1962)
offer accounts of Bini phonology and morphology. Several linguistic studies of Bini
in pedagogical or descriptive formats have followed. Dunn's (1968) An Introduction
to Bini is a training manual prepared for the American Peace Corps and as such
couches most of its language material in a limited variety of dialogue formats for the
prospective volunteer. An additional pedagogically oriented study is An Edo-English
Dictionary by Agheyisi (1986), which is intended for use in primary and secondary
schools. Stewart (1998) provides a theoretical interpretation of selected serial verb
constructions in Bini.
     Additional linguistic studies of Edoid speech varieties tend to be descriptive.
Ejele (1986) provides an overview of selected syntactic issues in Esan. Kari (1997)
provides a brief grammatical sketch of the Delta Edoid language Degema, which is
followed by a more detailed and illustrated descriptive grammar (2004).
     As for Emai, an initial lexicon and orthographic statement is offered by Schaefer
(1987), while Egbokhare (1990) presents an initial phonological analysis. An exten-
sive collection of Emai oral tradition texts is found in Oral Tradition Narratives of the
Emai People, Parts I and II (Schaefer and Egbokhare 1999b). This is complemented
more recently by A Dictionary of Emai: An Edoid Language of Nigeria (Schaefer and
Egbokhare 2007). Additional information on Emai is available in a number of papers
x | Prefaceby Schaefer and Egbokhare published in a variety of books and journal articles. Of
particular relevance to the future of Emai as a spoken medium is Schaefer and Eg-
bokhare (1999a), which found an intergenerational shift to English as home lan-
guage in the mid-1990s without a commensurate negative evaluation of vernacular
mother tongue.

1 Orthography and grammatical overview
Emai has no written tradition except as introduced in an initial orthographic state-
ment by Schaefer (1987) and utilized in the text collection of Schaefer and Egbo-
khare (1999) and a dictionary by Schaefer and Egbokhare (2007). To maintain some
consistency in discussion of linguistic issues in Emai, we follow the practice estab-
lished by these earlier works, although some changes regarding tone marking are
noted below. In general, segment representations follow conventions for Nigerian
languages set out in Williamson (1984) and adapted for Emai.

     Stop sounds occur at four places of articulation: bilabial, alveolar, velar, and
labiovelar. Fricatives articulate at four places: labiodental, alveolar, palatal and
velar. There are affricate sounds at only alveopalatal. Approximants appear at five
places of articulation: bilabial, alveolar, palatal, labiovelar and glottal. They show
allophonic relationships with nasal consonants at four places: bilabial, alveolar,
palatal and labiovelar. Alternation in three instances is conditioned by a nasal vow-
el (‘vb’~‘m,’ ‘w’~‘nw,’ and ‘y’~‘ny’) and in one instance by syntactic positioning
and/or syntactic category (‘l’~‘n’, Chapter 9, 9.1). The two approximants ‘h’ and ‘r’
fail to alternate with nasal consonants.
      In the following lexemes, stop sounds occur word initially.

Emai is a terraced-level tone language showing high, low, and down-stepped high.
For some word classes, inherent tone values distinguish words that in all other as-
pects of sound shape are identical. Nouns, adjectives and postverbal adverbs in
citation form express lexical meanings through tonal contrasts. Citation forms of
verbs, auxiliaries, and adverbial preverbs generally exhibit no tonal contrast, as
with other Edoid languages (Elugbe 1989). Emai verbs, auxiliaries, and preverbs are
assigned tone values reflecting grammatical properties of their constructions. In
large part these values correlate with the categories indicative and subjunctive
mood. More specifically, major patterns of tonal contrast derive from aspect (per-
fect, imperfect and prospective), modality (deontic and epistemic) and sentence
complement type.
     For Emai words composed of identical segments, predominantly nouns and ad-
verbs, tone values play a distinguishing role. Emai's high (H), down-stepped high
(!H) and low (L) tones combine in various ways within otherwise identical lexical
nouns, adjectives and postverbal adverbs. In orthographic practice, high tone is

by an acute accent immediately followed by a single quote. The last of these tones is
one pitch step lower than an immediately preceding high tone.ódòn                  òdón                   òkpá                   òkpà

Major word classes tend to reflect contrasting syllable structures, although no abso-
lute relation exists between category type and syllable character. All parts of speech
are vowel final. Nouns are uniformly vowel-initial. Verbs tend to be consonant ini-
tial, with a few being vowel initial. Adjectives are usually consonant initial, whereas
adverbs are either vowel- or consonant initial. Of the minor categories, some are
predominantly consonant initial with a few vowel initial forms (preverbs, postverbal
particles, complements). Other minor categories are vowel initial (determiners) with
a few consonant initial forms (intensifiers). The preposition class is consonant ini-
tial. Concord expression is vowel only with fixed tone patterns.
      In pronunciation, the syllabic character of word classes in phrasal or clausal
constructions is normally adjusted by one or another phonological process: vowel
6 | Orthography and grammatical overviewelision or glide formation. These processes lead to a divergence between the ortho-
graphic practice of employing citation forms and normal-rate pronunciation ren-
dered phonetically. Regardless of phonetic transformation through glide formation
or vowel elision, orthographic practice retains vowel segments in all word classes.
     Glide formation affects the close vowels [i] and [u] when they precede non-close
vowels within a lexical or syntactic constituent. These vowels alternate with the
glides [y] and [w], respectively, as illustrated by the verbs fi and ku when followed
by a noun phrase.fí    ópìà [fyópìà]                     kú    àmè [kwàmè]

pheme-final vowel. Elision differentially affects word classes, revealing complex
interactions between phonological and syntactic parameters. Vowel elision applica-
tion is restricted across major syntactic constituents like subject/predicate and pred-
icate/adverb. In normal pronunciation of the sentence below, neither the final vow-

transparent most easily with transitive verb phrases. When a lexical direct object
immediately follows a consonant initial verb with a single vowel, the final vowel of
the verb is omitted, while the initial vowel of the direct object is retained. Ortho-
graphic representation shows both vowels nonetheless, as shown by comparing

some level of morpheme transparency in orthographic practice, elided vowels in

1.5 Basic sentence types and pitch register
Basic grammatical relations in Emai show the order Subject-Verb-Object (SVO).
Declarative statements with transitive verbs reveal a subject noun phrase (ólí ómòhè
‘the man’) followed by a verb (é ‘eat’) and its direct object (ólí émàè ‘the food’).(1) ólí ómòhè é         ólí émàè.
    the man PRP.eat the food
    ‘The man has eaten the food.’Sentence types contrast with respect to voice-register and tonal pattern. Imperative
constructions utilize a normal voice register.(2) è ólí émàè.
    eat the food
    ‘Eat the food.’Declaratives rely on a normal voice register as well.(3) ólí ómòhè é         ólí émàè.
    the man PRP.eat the food
    ‘The man has eaten the food.’However, polar interrogatives (yes/no questions), while manifesting the same word
order as declaratives and essentially the same tonal patterns, employ a higher pitch
register.(4) ólí ómòhè é         ólí émàè?
    the man PRP.eat the food
    ‘Has the man eaten the food?’Rhetorical questions are also expressed through this higher register, adding a final
extra-high tone (e.g. é) to a lexical low tone (émàè).(5) ólí ómòhè ò ó è ólí émàèé?
    the man SC C eat the food
    ‘The man is eating the food, is he?’
10 | Orthography and grammatical overview1.6 Basic syntactic constraints on tone distribution
Tonal configurations in Emai reveal the interaction of lexical tone with syntactic
tone values derived from grammatical categories and their placement. Traditional
phrase heads such as nouns and verbs exhibit tonal variability controlled by pres-
ence or absence of modifying constituents or of adjacent phrases. For purposes of
illustration, we rely on noun phrases and monotransitive or ditransitive verb
phrases to convey an overview of the nature of this variability, although a full ac-
count of principles underlying sentence, clause and phrase tone remains to be un-
dertaken.

     Here it is. It is I who am called Monday. Do you not see these people who live in
this very place? It is as eye witnesses that all live in this very place.
     There were two women who were in the village. They were called Aaegbe and
Ionlesen. These two women, they were more beautiful than anything that had ever
yet been experienced. This one who was called Aaegbe, she was beauty beyond
measure. Witness this thing. These are women? Where among womankind did these
ones come from? So Aaegbe prepared her things. She told Ionlesen, there is no other
job that one will do other than prostitution. That one said it. It isn’t so, is it?
     This Aaegbe who must have had this conversation, a wound made havoc on her
leg. It is with a rag that she wraps it. But it was this Aaegbe alone that men liked
more, it is they who searched up and down for her. She said, “Look at it, Ionlesen,
since it was discovered that it is I that men are fond of, one surely hasn’t found how
one will deal with it. But the wound which is on this leg of mine, this leg will be
exchanged for another one.” Ionlesen said, “It isn’t so is it? The money that will be
made afterward, it will be mixed together.” Aegbe said, “It will be mixed together. It
will be saved and used to eat food.” Ionlesen said, “It is fine.”
     Just as they were having this conversation, three young men came. At once,
they knocked on the door, ratatattat. Yes, Aaegbe said, “I say that I have come.
What are you searching for?” They said, “Aaegbe. I say that we will take you to La-
gos.” Aaegbe said, “Lagos? Ionlesen, I say come, this wound, it does not know how
to become large. When I remove the cloth from it, I say that men will disperse and
run away.” Ionlesen said, “There isn’t anything else to do. I will just hold it for you.”
980 | Sample oral narrativeIonlesen then said, “Aaegbe, I say bring your leg.” So they exchanged legs with
each other. Each leg locked into place. Aaegbe then said, “It isn’t so, is it?” Aaegbe
then said, I want to bathe. So she bathed don’t you know. Ionlesen picked out her
things. She then said, “I am coming, in order to enter the room.” After she glanced
about, she did not see Aaegbe. So she started to sing a song.
    SONG: This village, if you see Aaegbe, if you see Aaegbe, Aaegbe of havoc,
Aaegbe of wretchedness, Aaegbe of ingratitude, who does not know how to return a

Aaegbe of havoc, Aaegbe of wretchedness, Aaegbe of ingratitude, who does not

    Don’t you see it? One does not lead another one on to some place, as might be
thought. I wonder whether you are seeing it. As a result, Ionlesen picked out her
things. She approached the door. She then said, “A group of young men of this
kind.’ She then said, “I ask you for the person I am searching for.” One said, “Who
are you surely searching for?” Ionlesen said, “Who do you surely search for?” Ion-
lesen then said, “Aaegbe.” One said, “It is beauty that has overtaken her.” Another
said, “Yes, Aaegbe, she picked out her things just recently, she proceeded to Afuze,
don’t you know.” Ionlesen also put her legs to walking.
    SONG: This village, if you see Aaegbe, if you see Aaegbe, Aaegbe of havoc,
Aaegbe of wretchedness, Aaegbe of ingratitude, who does not know how to return a

walking. She reached Afuze. One said, “Just recently Aaegbe came out from this
room. When you see her, she and the men, she took the men to her. When they posi-
tion each other noisily, they crash onto the ground from the bed. They make noises
with their bodies. They crash on the ground from the bed. They make noises with
their bodies. They thump on the mat.” One said, “How will one deal with this one?”
One said, “Aaegbe, I say that she just came out recently. She proceeded to Otuo.”
Ionlesen said yes, it is walking that I have started. I intend to do goodness, I do it
but what do I get in return? So she started to sing a song.
    SONG: This village, if you see Aaegbe, if you see Aaegbe, Aaegbe of havoc,

    Don’t you see it? So Ionlesen reached Otou. After she reached Otuo, she encoun-
tered young men assessing each other. Some were jumping away at the window. She
then said, “I ask you please, rescue me.” One asked her, “What happened to you?”
She said, “It is Aaegbe I search for.” One said, “Aaegbe? She just picked up her

should happen to move to is the place where I start out from. So Ionlesen then
picked out her things.

      It is just so, isn’t it? So Ionlesen started on her journey, briskly moving on. So
she reached Benin City, don’t you know. After she reached Benin City, she encoun-
tered that the entirety of the young men, they were seething a great deal. Sweat was
overcoming everyone completely on their shoulder blade. Ionlesen said, “How?”
Ionlesen said, “I say that it is Aaegbe I am searching for.” One said he took one
woman who was beautiful in that way just recently. Another said, “Yes, she picked
out her things. She said she was going to Lagos.” Ionlesen then said, “Is it I who am
this one? The wound will infest me today. I will be infested by this wound today.
The wound, it is, Aaegbe then told me, take, hold it for me. I held the wound for her.
It is an act of goodness that I performed.” So Ionlesen walked to Lagos.
      SONG: This village, if you see Aaegbe, if you see Aaegbe, Aaegbe of havoc,

Aaegbe of havoc, Aaegbe of wretchedness, Aaegbe of ingratitude, who does not

      That is how it is. There passed one market week, one fortnight, walking is what
Ionlesen did. It is she. Her toes were about to wither away on the road to Lagos. “I
will just ensure that I will see her today.” Ionlesen, she shuffled into Lagos. The
people said, “Greetings.” Another said, “Greetings.” This one said, “Greetings.” She
then said, “This thing you speak, this is not the language I know. I say that it is a
person I search for. There is no one who will give me a helping hand?” One said,
“Whom do you search for?” She said, “One small girl that is called Aaegbe.” One
said, “Go into that room, you will meet her in there.” So Ionlesen entered the room
don’t you know. It was men she met. She said, “I ask you about the woman you
carried into this room.” One said, “Yes, it is Aaegbe who proceeded to Ajegunle and
entered inside Lagos. What? Ajegunle inside Lagos.” “Is it Ajegunle that she now
entered?” He then said, “It is just so.”

982 | Sample oral narrative     It is that way that one experienced it don’t you know. So Ionlesen reached
Ajegunle. After she was coming, she encountered young men. What does one now
call this kind of person? “I ask you to allow me to pass, for it is a person I am search-
ing for.” One said, “I say that Aaegbe is just in the room.” After Ionlesen came to the
room, she found that Aaegbe had plaited the hair with an enticing hair style (one-
looks-at-me-does-not-look-elsewhere). Ionlesen then said, “Aaegbe, I am coming so
that your wound should infest you, so that this wound should infest you. You asked
me to hold your wound for you. The wound, you gave it to me. You shuffled into
Lagos. It is I who now experienced suffering.” Aaegbe who is infested with a wound,
she is beautiful throughout. Aaegbe, take the wound. Ionlesen said, “It was surely
not discovered how one will deal with it. Since it happened this way, bring your
shin in order that we should exchange them, in order for you to take hold of your
wound.” Aaegbe pulled her buttocks near her back. I say that it is so, isn’t it? Ion-
lesen said, “I intend to also now reach womanhood of my own and exhibit beauty
like you. For, indeed, we should reach womanhood together.” So Aaegbe brought
her shin. So Ionlesen brought her shin. So they each fit their own shin into place.
This is the reason that when a person bruises a leg at the shin, the wound it makes
on the shin is messy. The story just finishes that way.

6.6 Ideophonic adverbs
Ideophonic adverbs articulate meanings that reflect speaker perspective. They need
not express a meaning shared by speaker and hearer and as such are not open to
interrogation by a hearer. Like other adverbs, they occupy postverbal position and
induce high tone spread in an immediately preceding noun phrase constituent.
     Ideophonic adverbs assume a variety of morphological shapes and often ex-
press meanings typically lexicalized in English verbs. Some exhibit reduplication or
triplication.gbírígbírí ‘jerkily’                      dúdúdú    ‘very dark’
ghóíghóí ‘glisteningly’                   kpákpákpá ‘tremblingly’
púpúpú ‘flappingly’                       kpékpékpé ‘shiveringly’
kpíkpíkpí ‘flutteringly’                  gbágbágbá ‘slappingly’Others fail to exhibit either reduplication or triplication.píí ‘flingingly’                          wóò ‘smackingly’
váí ‘snatchingly’                         gbìó ‘crackingly’
bóí ‘poppingly’                           yáá ‘simmeringly’
yóò ‘whoosh’                              húú ‘pungently’Ideophonic adverbs co-occur with a single verb or a few verbs of similar sense.
While they seem closely related to clause assertion, ideophonic adverbs do not fall

14.1 Conditional relations
Relations of logical or temporal condition (henceforth “conditional relations”) are
marked as subordinate in multi-clause constructions. They show an auxiliary in one
class of constructions and a complementizer in another. Among conditional rela-
tions are several semantic types. Linked subordinate and matrix clauses constrain
aspect and modality, their linear order, and subject coreference.
    Hypothetical form kha participates in four conditional types: perfect, imperfect,
prospective, and counter-to-fact, respectively illustrated below.(1) a. ólí ómòhè khà        káàwó óvbí óì, ò gbé             évìè á.
       the man PRP.HYP look.at child his he PRP.break tears CS
       ‘When the man looked at his child, he burst into tears.’
    b. ólì òkpòsò khà        áà záwó òhí, ò ó             vbì ìwè.
       the woman PRP.HYP RC see Ohi he PRP.enter LOC house
       ‘Whenever the woman saw Ohi, she entered the house.’s
    c. ólì òkpòsò khà        míé òhí, ó ló         ò    vbì ìwè.
       the woman PRP.HYP see Ohi she PRED enter LOC house
       ‘If the woman sees Ohi, she will enter the house.’
    d. ólí ómóhé khà         míé òhí, ó khà          ó      vbì ìwè.
       the man PAP.HYP see Ohi he PAP.HYP enter LOC house
       ‘If the man had seen Ohi, he would have entered the house.’    Independent of these constructions, kha serves as an epistemic auxiliary. In that
function it assumes the existence of an unspecified hypothetical condition that
controls event realization and asserts that had this condition been fulfilled, an event
would have occurred. Epistemic kha shows low tone and appears with a marked
melody subject phrase (right edge high tone).(2) a. ólí ómóhé khà       gbé ólí ófè.

Concessive relations are marked as subordinate in multi-clause constructions. For
one construction class, a single epistemic auxiliary or a combination of epistemic
auxiliaries express concessiveness. Concessive relations occur as perfect, prospec-
tive and counter-to-fact types. A second, less robust class relies on a complex com-
plementizer. Linked concessive clauses constrain aspect, modality, linear order, and
subject coreference.
     Concessive constructions rely on the presumed truth of one proposition as the
basis for judging the truth value of another. The proposition to which truth is con-
ceded is marked in Emai by epistemic modality form Concessive rere.8 Its matrix
clause is framed by various auxiliary forms. Concessives are identifiable in three
construction types: perfect, prospective and counterfactual, as illustrated below.(62) a. ò rérè          tá    ìyó, ó kpé'            ù.

        ‘Although he spoke that way, he still died.’

Temporal relations in multi-clause constructions are designated as subordinate by
several grammatical strategies, namely aspect and relative tense auxiliary (ke, kpe)
or aspectualizer preverb (ghe); complementizer (bi) and Concessive auxiliary (re);
bare noun relative clause head in construction with verb re ‘take’ in series; or verb
in series (se, de) with following embedded complement or bare noun relative clause
head. Temporal relations coded include succession, concidence, condition, extent
and anticipation. Linked subordinate and matrix clauses constrain linear order,
aspect and modality, as well as subject coreference.

endpoint occurs with addition of aspectualizer ghe. Construction events are con-
strained as to linear order and subject coreference.

Relations of conjunction and disjunction are expressed in multi-clause construc-
tions. Conjoined clauses are marked as contrastive by one form while conjoined
complements are so marked by another. Disjunction is marked in each clause. Con-
struction markers impose polarity on clause union. Although contrastive and dis-
junctive forms exist, there is no marker for clause conjunction (e.g. ‘and’).

multiple verb roots that otherwise occur as serial verb sequences or to verb stems

entities, instruments and places.

Grammatical relations that undergo relativization, i.e. that correspond to head noun
of the relative clause, include subject, direct object, indirect object, locative, posses-
sor and adjunct. Of these, subject and possessor require an obligatory resumptive,

object in double object complements. Remaining grammatical relations (direct ob-

Lexically headed relative clauses co-occur with all nominal modifier categories,
although forms within categories may be constrained. Relative clauses combine
with definite article ólí/élí under discourse conditions where the speaker wishes to
re-establish shared knowledge with the hearer about the referent of the relativized
nominal. Without a strong discourse condition, speakers tend not to use the definite
article with a relative clause.

4.3.3.1.1    Possession ísì / ésì
Two forms of the Associative exist: ésì and ísì. Each occurs under distinct semantic
conditions. ésì is restricted to expressions of temporary location, whereas ísì ex-

Attributive complements within complex noun phrases show marked and unmarked
patterns. Marked attributives are signaled by Relator li. It follows a head noun,
which undergoes high tone spread, and precedes an attributive complement. li
complements include abstract nominals, adjectives, nominalized stative verbs, and
deictic pronouns. Unmarked attributives lack Relator li and express distributive and
quantitative meanings in contrast to li marked collective and size meanings.

2.1.1 Noun inflectionEmai evinces a remnant gender system of number bearing prefixes attached to nom-
inal roots. Aspects of this system are also evident in prefixes attached to postnomi-
nal modifiers as well as pronouns expressing varying syntactic functions.
     Number inflection determines the shape of some nominal and modifier stems.
For a limited set of nominal roots belonging to human, animate and inanimate clas-
ses as well as body-part locus and abstractions, a number contrast is marked by
vowel prefixes. There is a tendency for singular to be realized by back, mid vowels
(o- and o-) and plural by front, non-low vowels (i-, e-, e-). It is only the mid low vow-
el (a-) that is used for singular and plural marking. Tone of the prefixal pair does not
correlate with number; nor does it correlate with gender.
     Overt number marking leading to noun class pairs and thus genders is not com-
prehensive in Emai. The number of nouns in each remnant gender is variable, some
exhibiting only a single root. And in contrast to gender systems of the Bantu type
found in other parts of Africa, no root participates in more than one noun class pair.

ties that fall within the classes human, animate, inanimate, abstract and/or locus.
Based on their semantic profiles, few remnant genders reflect a single identifiable
semantic class. Of Emai’s 11 genders, all with mid back vowels designating singular
(i.e. o- ~ i-, o- ~ e-, o- ~ e-, o- ~ i-) exhibit human nouns except o- ~ a-; it shows body-
part items. The gender u- ~ i- is the most clearly non-human, since it reveals all clas-

gender classes reflect a generic or basic level of abstraction. Several classes identify-
ing fauna, moreover, identify entities reflective of a pastoral lifestyle (e.g. sheep,
cow and goat), despite the fact that such a lifestyle is incompatible with the current
ecological environment of the Emai. In addition, Emai gender classes tend not to
include root forms that reflect an agricultural lifestyle (e.g yam, maize and beans).

      Within Emai’s grammatical system, agreement or concord linked to gender is no
longer functional. Perfect aspect and prospective aspect evince no morphological
agreement marking. However, a remnant agreement system is evident in imperfect
aspect, where continuous and habitual morphemes are distinguished by tone.
      Continuous aspect in the third person is expressed by high tone ó, preceded
immediately by a low tone subject concord (SC) marker (ò) and a lexically headed
subject constituent with low tone at its right edge (ólí ómòhè, élí ímóhè).(1) ólí ómòhè / élí ímóhè ò ó è ólí émàè.
    the man      the men SC C eat the food
    ‘The man is / The men are eating food.’    Habitual is similarly framed except for tone, which in third peson is conveyed
by low tone ò preceded by a subject concord marker with high tone (ó) and a lexical-
ly headed constituent with right edge high tone (ólí ókpósó ná, élí íkpósó ná).(2) ólí ókpósó ná / élí íkpósó ná      ó ò shèn úkpùn.
    the woman this the women these SC H sell cloth
    ‘This woman sells / These women sell cloth.’     As clausal expressions in the imperfect illustrate, neither number nor gender
impacts shape of the agreement marker. There is no effect on subject concord pho-
nological shape by indexing of grammatical number in the subject constituent (pre-
determiner ólí ~ élí with o- ~ e-) or by gender contrast of lexical head nouns
(ókpósó/íkpósó with o- ~ i- or ómòhè/ímóhè with o- ~ i-). Number and gender distinc-
tions in agreement marking are thus neutralized.
     Remnant agreement is evident within noun phrases, where a select group of ad-
jectives must agree in number with their head noun. Emai attributive phrases
marked by the particle li index grammatical number on adjective forms
(òkhúá/èkhúá, óbín'/ébín') that modify gender bearing nouns. Hence, the grammati-
cal number conveyed by the initial vowel of an attributive adjective (o- for singular
and e- for plural) varies in agreement with grammatical number of the initial vowel
of the head noun (e- for singular and i- or e- for plural).

Compound lexemes in Emai reflect three compositional patterns. Analytic com-
pounds consist of two noun stems (N-N), sometimes three (N-[N-N]). Synthetic com-
pounds consist of a prefix followed by a verb root and a noun stem (prefix-V-N).
Phrasal compounds utilize grammatical markers in their compositional make up (N-
marker-N).
                                                           Lexical compounds | 552.4.1 Analytic compoundsAnalytic compounds of one structural type consist of two noun stems. Head of the
compound is the left noun stem. Relative to taxonomic structural levels, analytic
compounds tend to express specific or subordinate level designation relative to a
noncompound articulated basic or prototypic concept. The right stem tends to de-
note a more specific referent relative to the more general class referent of the left
noun stem. Constituent relations between noun stems reflect an obligatory inalien-
able relation, contrasting with an alienable relation in corresponding syntactic
phrases with a grammatical marker. For some compound lexemes where meaning is
not derived compositionally, a metaphoric interpretation is required.
     Analytic compounds encode objects that fall into subcategories of flora and
fauna as well as fish, insects, birds, containers, location, time units, food items,
traditional belief, kin relations and social roles. Example compounds and their con-
stituents follow.

7 Noncanonical constructions
Noncanonical constructions in Emai express the information status of a clause or
clause constituent in discourse. Discourse-defined constructions include positive
focus (PF) and negative focus (NF), topicalization, antitopic or right dislocation,
information questions, sentence affirmation (SA) and sentence negation (SN). Each
construction is morphosyntactically marked except topicalization, where intonation
downturn follows the topic constituent. Except for sentence affirmation and sen-
tence negation, each construction is characterized by an additional constituent that
precedes or follows its matrix clause. The resulting discourse position, typically a
noun phrase, corresponds to a matrix clause grammatical relation. Each construc-
tion also co-occurs with at least one other construction type, although distinct con-
structions never affect the same matrix clause constituent.(1) a. ólí óvbékhán nà lí ó gbé'                 ólí ákhè á.
       the youth        this PF he PAP.break the pot CS
       ‘It was this youth who broke the pot.’
    b. ólí óvbékhán nà kí ó gbé'                 ólí ákhè á.
       the youth        this NF he PAP.break the pot CS
       ‘It wasn't this youth who broke the pot.’
    c. ólí óvbékhán nà, ò gbé                ólí ákhè á.
       the youth        this he PRP.break the pot CS
       ‘As for this youth, he broke the pot.’
    d. ó gbé'           ólí ákhè á, í khì ólí óvbékhán nà.
       he PAP.break the pot CS ID be the youth               this
       ‘He broke the pot, that is this youth.’
    e. óé' ó gbé'             ólí ákhè á?
       who he PAP.break the pot CS
       ‘Who broke the pot?’
    f. érí' ólí óvbékhán gbé'           ólí ákhè á.
       SA the youth         PAP.break the pot CS
       ‘Indeed, the youth broke the pot.’
    g. kí ólí óvbékhán gbé'              ólí ákhè á ò.
       SN the youth          PAP.break the pot CS INT
       ‘It isn't the case that the youth broke the pot (contrary to your opinion).’7.1 Noun phrase focus
Focus constructions assume a contrast between speaker and hearer knowledge
regarding the information status of a nominal referent or predicate event. Construc-
348 | Noncanonical constructionstion purpose is to align hearer and speaker knowledge. Focus position in this con-
struction expresses information that is not shared by speaker and hearer. Its follow-
ing matrix clause conveys shared information.
     Focus position is marked in affirmative structures by the morpheme li/ni and in
negative structures by ki. Focus position immediately precedes a matrix clause and
its constituent corresponds to a grammatical relation in the matrix clause. For ex-
ample, the focus position constituent ólí émà followed by li/ni or ki corresponds to
the direct object relation following the matrix verb shen. Focus position noun
phrases manifest an unmarked tone pattern, i.e. they accept a right edge low tone.
On the other hand, focus construction matrix clauses inflect for a limited range of
aspects, all with a right edge high tone subject.(2) a. ólí émà lí ólí ómóhé ló        shèn ákhò.
       the yam PF the man PRED sell tomorrow
       ‘It was the yam that the man will sell tomorrow.’
    b. ólí émà kí ólí ómóhé ló        shèn ákhò.
       the yam NF the man PRED sell tomorrow
       ‘It wasn't the yam that the man will sell tomorrow.’Across affirmative and negative focus types, only positive focus allows omission of
the construction marker. When li/ni is omitted, vowel elision does not affect phono-
logical shape of either focus noun phrase (ólí émà) or matrix clause initial constitu-
ent (ólí ómóhé).(3) ólí émà ólí ómóhé shén'-ì.

tion corresponding to a focus constituent. They also limit nominal structure types in
focus position. As well, they constrain marking of their matrix clause as to inflec-
tion, auxiliaries and preverbs.

focus constitutent with one of three strategies. The first of these affects matrix sub-
ject, possessor or first object in a double object complement. Each shows a pronoun
corresponding to the focus position constituent. A positive or negative focus posi-
tion noun phrase (ólí ómòhè) corresponds to a third person singular pronoun (o ‘he’)
in matrix subject position.

auxiliaries and preverbs. Regarding mood, focus constructions never appear as
imperatives or prohibitives. Relative to polarity, both affirmative and negative focus
constructions appear as polar questions (ólí émà lí / kí ólí ómóhé shén'-ì? [the yam PF
NF the man PAP.sell-F] ‘Was / Wasn’t it the yam that the man sold?’).
     In their matrix clauses, affirmative focus constructions allow perfect negation
marked by ì. Negative focus constructions disallow it (ólí émá nà òkpá lí / *kí ólí
ómóhé í ì shèn [the yam this alone PF NF the man SC NEG sell] ‘It was this yam alone
which the man did not sell’).

aspect, they inflect for Past perfect, imperfect Habitual or prospective Predictive.6

verbs that occur, there is a tendency to require a nondeclarative, polar interrogative
structure in negative focus constructions.
      As a class, aspectualizers interact with focus construction mood and polarity.
Matrix clauses linked to a positive focus position allow aspectualizers Repetitive che
(ólí émà lí ólí ómóhé ché' shèn [the yam PF the man PAP.REP sell] ‘It was the yam

ómóhé sé' shèn [yam alone PF the man PAP.DUR sell] ‘It was one yam that the man
still sold’). They reject Punctual ghe, regardless of polarity or mood.
      Negative focus matrix clauses accept all phasal aspectualizers but Punctual ghe.
They do so provided the construction assumes a polar interrogative form: che (ólí
émà kí ólí ómóhé ché' shèn? [the yam NF the man PAP.REP sell] ‘Wasn't it the yam

shèn [the yam PF NF the man SC CON sell] ‘It was / wasn’t the yam that the man
went to sell’).

shèn [yam my PF the man PAP.PA sell] ‘It was my yam that the man at one time

(ìmátó nà kí ólí ómóhé yà dé élá úkpè? [car this NF the man PAP.PA buy TP year]
‘Wasn't it this car that the man used to buy in the year we discussed?’) and mo (émá
mè kí ólí ómóhé mó' shèn? [yam my NF the man PAP.PA sell] ‘Wasn't it my yam that

5 Pronouns and conjunction
Emai pronouns express relations relative to linguistic or situational context. They
reflect five basic types: personal, bound (anaphoric), interrogative, locative and
impersonal. Exponents of these types can reflect case, person, number, gender,
and/or definiteness. In characterizing Emai grammatical structure, both overt pro-
noun and zero (gapped) pronoun prove useful.
     Zero pronoun is illustrated by the syntactic position following the transitive
verb nwu ‘take.’ This verb is subcategorized for a direct object. nwu takes a pronoun
(e.g. óì ‘it’) in the absence of a lexical noun. In series with another verb (e.g. hian
‘cut’), as well as in other structural patterns, nwu also takes a zero pronoun.(1) a. ólí ókpósó ló     nwú óì ní émè.
       the woman PRED take it APP me
       ‘The woman will give it to me.’
    b. ólí ókpósó ló     hìàn éànmì nwú ní émè.
       the woman PRED cut meat take APP me
       ‘The woman will cut meat in order to give it to me.’5.1 Definite personal pronouns

and plural), case (nominative, accusative, dative and genitive) and discourse status

Emai shows three bound pronouns co-referring to a preceding noun phrase. Reflex-
ive and Reciprocal must have their antecedent in the same clause. Logophoric pro-
noun antecedents cannot be in the same clause.
    Logophoric (LOG) pronouns are employed in narrative discourse to track gram-
matical subject of a communication or cognition verb (Chapter 13, 13.3.3). Limited to
third person, logophoric pronouns reflect case (subject/non-subject grammatical
relations) and number (singular/plural). Their form does not distinguish between
nonsubject position and positions defined by discourse status (i.e. focus or topic).

11.11 Forcible dispossession
Emai complex predicates characterize forcible dispossession of an entity vis-à-vis an
unmentioned event participant. V1 do ‘do in stealth’ expresses forcible disposses-
sion of NP2 by NP1. V2 consists of a transitive object manipulation verb (e.g. nwu
‘take a singleton,’ hua ‘take a plurality’) or a consumption activity verb (e.g. da
‘drink’). V2 expresses the resulting possession relationship between NP1 as posses-
sor and NP2 as possessum. English translation of predication sense engages the verb
steal or collocations of dispossession, e.g. carry off.(342) a. òjè dó                   ólí úkpùn nwú.
         Oje PRP.do.in.stealth the cloth take
         ‘Oje stole / carried off the cloth.’
      b. òjè dó                   élí íkpùn húá.
         Oje PRP.do.in.stealth the cloths take
         ‘Oje stole / carried off the cloths.’
      c. àlèkè dó                    ójé ényò dá.
         Aleke PRP.do.in.stealth Oje wine drink
         ‘Aleke secretly drank Oje’s wine / stole Oje's wine to drink.’V2 position in complex dispossession predications rejects pro-verb u ‘do.’(343) *òjè dó                   óì ú.
       Oje PRP.do.in.stealth it do
       ‘Oje did it in stealth.’    Complex predicates with do fail to deconstruct strictly. V2, when transitive, oc-
curs with NP1 as subject and NP2 as direct object. V2 never occurs with NP2 as in-
transitive subject. As simple predicates, V2 forms assume a state of possessum ac-
quisition, their meanings contrasting with the loss asserted by complex
dispossession predicates.(344) a. òjè nwú        ólí úkpùn.
         Oje PRP.take the cloth
         ‘Oje carried the cloth.’
      b. òjè húá        élí íkpùn.
         Oje PRP.take the cloths
         ‘Oje carried the cloths.’As for V1 do, it does not occur as a transitive shape with NP1 as subject and NP2 as
direct object or as an intransitive shape with NP1 or NP2 as subject.

Emai complex predicates articulate a state of resistance to a presumed change of
possession. V2 expresses resistance to possession change that results in retention of
possessum. Transitive verbs of object manipulation occur as V1 (e.g. nwu ‘take’).
Translation equivalents for the complex predications engage verbs hold, keep and
hide, respectively, with V2 forms moe, yaa and hee.

are restricted by number, animacy, syntactic shape, nominal type, and linear order.

phrases link two names (khì ójé khì òhí ‘both Oje and Ohi’), two modified nouns (khì

(*khì ólí ómóhé khì élí ívbékhán ‘both the man and the youths’).
    Correlative phrases restrict positioning of lexical nouns according to animacy
and number. They correlate an animate and an inanimate noun (khì éwé mè khì
úbélé mè ‘both my goat and my gourd’), two inanimate nouns (khì ólí ókpán khì ólí
úkpún ‘both the gourd and the cloth’) or two animate nouns (khì éwé khì óókhó ‘both
a goat and a chicken’). When Correlative phrases link human and nonhuman, ani-
mate nouns, the human noun precedes the animate noun (khì ójé khì ólí áwá ‘both
Oje and the dog,’ *khì ólí áwá khì ójé). When Correlative phrases link human and
inanimate nouns, the human noun precedes the inanimate noun (khì ójé khì úbélé
‘both Oje and his gourd,’ *khì úbélé khì ójé).

7.3.1 Matrix clause marking of topic relationA matrix clause grammatical relation corresponding to topic is marked in one of two
ways. For the grammatical relations subject, direct object, indirect object, locative,
and possessor, a pronoun is used. For nonlocative adverbial adjuncts, a zero pro-
noun is employed.
    When a topic constituent corresponds to matrix subject, direct object or indirect
object, a pronominal anaphor (or resumptive pronoun) appears in the respective
matrix position. The pronoun is obligatory. Pronoun form for third person for exam-
ple (o, óì, áìn) is determined by grammatical relation (subject, direct object and
indirect object, respectively) and number agreement vis-à-vis the topic constituent.(32) a. ólí ómòhè, ó shén'       ólí úkpùn lí      ólì òkpòsò.
        the man he PAP.sell the cloth APP the woman
        ‘As for the man, he sold the cloth to the woman.’

        the cloth the man PRP.sell it APP the woman
        ‘As for the cloth, the man sold it to the woman.’
     c. ólì òkpòsò, ólí ómóhé shén'          ólí úkpùn ní áìn.
        the woman the man PAP.sell the cloth APP her
        ‘As for the woman, the man sold the cloth to her.’When the topic constituent corresponds to a possessor following Associative ísì, a
genitive pronoun (òí) in possessor position is obligatory.(33) ólì ònwìmè, éghó' ísì òí úé'-ì.

     ‘As for the farmer, his money is lost.’When a topic constituent corresponds to complement of a vbi locative, either of two
marking strategies is followed. If the vbi phrase serves as an adjunct, anaphoric
locative pronoun o occupies complement position following vbi.

quantifiers, collective èrèmé occurs but distributive òdóòdé does not: (èrèmé /

partitive vbi phrase. Existential partitive quantifier ósò appears in topic position
alone or as head of a partitive vbi phrase (ósò / ósó vbì ò, ólí ókpósó gbé' óì [cer-

élìyó occurs (élìyó, ólí ómóhé gbé' óì [that.kind.one the man PAP.kill it] ‘As for that
kind of one, the man killed it’), whereas contrastive kindred ódàn does not (*ódàn,

one, the man killed it’). In addition, neither kindred form appears in topic position
when head of a partitive vbi phrase.

cloth, he killed the rat’).11

Right dislocation (RD) or antitopic constructions consist of two major constituents, a
matrix clause with a falling intonation contour followed by a constituent wherein a
noun phrase is preceded by Equational Identity copula khi and its obligatory Identi-
ty subject pronoun í. A right dislocated constituent functions to identify the referent
of a matrix clause grammatical relation assumed by the speaker to be unclear.(45) ólí ómóhé shén'      óì, í khì ólí émà.

     ‘The man sold it, that is the yam.’RD constructions constrain syntactic shape of the right dislocated constituent and
restrict matrix clause inflection, auxiliaries and preverbs. RD occurrence in embed-
ded or subordinate clauses is also limited. As for RD position itself, it corresponds to
grammatical relations subject, monotransitive direct object and locative argument,
with additional restrictions imposed on those relations.

7.2 Predicate focus
Predicate focus constructions exhibit a focus constituent with a nominalized verb
followed by a matrix clause. In focus position, they employ the matrix clause verb’s
gerundive form (uVERBmi) (Chapter 2, 2.3.2). Regardless of positive or negative fo-
cus, these constructions are highly constrained and very infrequently used. More so
than nominal focus, predicate focus constructions severely constrain modifiers in
focus position as well as auxiliaries and preverbs in their matrix clause.

rundive constituents. With unmodified gerundive nominals in focus position, the
positive focus particle itself is optional.(25) úkhùmí (lí) òhí khú'         ólí éwè.

position. It only occurs with gerundives that are modified.(26) úkhùmí lì kéré / *úkhùmí kí òhí khú'               ólí éwè.

kind’ as well as unmarked attributive phrases, e.g. óbè ‘bad.’ údàmí never accepts
deictic kindred, demonstratives, numerals or quantifiers.

Topic (left-dislocation) constructions manifest two structural constituents. They
exhibit a topic in leftmost position characterized by falling intonation (represented
362 | Noncanonical constructionsorthographically by a comma) and a matrix clause in which the topic bears a gram-
matical relation. Topic position holds information shared by speaker and hearer.
The matrix clause expresses nonshared information.
    Topic constructions limit the syntactic character of topic position and its matrix
clause. In the matrix clause, grammatical marking of the position corresponding to
topic differs from that in focus constructions, as does the distribution of auxiliaries
and preverbs.

(ó zá' ú ìyó [he PAP.RES act DMD] ‘As a result, he acted that way’). No other epistem-
ic forms occur, particularly speculative Dubitatives vba and bia, and Certaintive ma.

quent kpe, and Anterior ke, as unacceptable ke suggests (*ó ké' ú ìyó [he PAP.ANT
do DMD] ‘He acted that way afterward’).
     Intransitive u limits preverbs. It disallows manner-demonstrative preverbs ìná
and ìyó. With aspectualizers, intransitive u permits some phasal forms, permitting
Repetitive che (ò chéè ú ìyó [he PRP.REP do DMD] ‘He acted that way again’) and
Additive gbo (ò gbóò ú ìyó [he PRP.ADD do DMD] ‘He acted that way too’) but not
Durative se or Punctual ghe. Intransitive u allows only the boundary aspectualizer
Past Absolute ya (ólí ómóhé yà ú ìyó [the man PAP.PA do DMD] ‘The man used to act
that way’). It rejects Past Absolute mo, Ingressive ya, Egressive mo and Conative òó.
     Intransitive u admits only one evaluative preverb, kuku (ólí ómóhé kú'kù ú ìyó
[the man PAP.POEV do DMD] ‘The man afterall acted that way’). It rejects duu ‘for no
reason’ and woo ‘instead.’

gbúdu (ólí ómóhé gbú'dù ú ìyó [the man PAP.courageously do DMD] ‘The man coura-

dobo (ólí ómóhé dóbó' óì ú ìyó [the man PAP.REFL him do DMD] ‘The man himself

Information questions are shaped by interrogative pronouns or by pronouns in con-
struction with other grammatical or lexical forms. Interrogative pronouns in most
circumstances occur in clause initial question position. Structural shape of infor-
mation questions varies along several dimensions. Some interrogative pronouns
require a matrix clause auxiliary, preverb, postverbal particle or verb in series. One
question type shows no interrogative pronoun.
     For three interrogative pronouns their sound shape varies according to phono-
logical environment. In echo questions where each occurs in situ, interrogative pro-
nouns exhibit a final vowel sequence èé with low high tone: óèé ‘who,’ émèé ‘what’
and ébèé ‘where.’ In direct and indirect questions, where they are clause initial,
phonological realization of these pronouns is controlled by an adjacent segment.
When the following segment is a vowel, the e is retained with high downstep tone
(óé', émé', ébé', respectively). When the following segment is a consonant, the [e] is
realized as [i] and retains a high downstep tone (óí', émí', ébí', respectively).
     Interrogative pronouns are fundamental to information questions. Each as-
sumes a basic or derived shape. Four reflect the semantic categories Space (‘where’),
Person (‘who’), Object (‘what’) and Quantity/Cost (‘how many/how much’).ébé' / ébí' ‘where’                       óé' / óí' ~ éé' / éí' ‘who’
émé' / émí' ‘what’                        ékà ‘how much / how many’Three interrogative pronouns formulate a question constituent with a head noun (N)
to articulate another four information question types: Possession (‘whose’), Kindred
(‘what kind’), Quantity (‘how many’) and Cost (‘how much’).

Emai complex predicates characterize the manner of a directional change of locative
state. They do so relative to a closed class of intransitive and transitive directional
motion verbs as V2. Manner expression is either intransitive or transitive, as illus-
trated by the V1 forms la ‘run’ and sua ‘push.’ Regardless of transitivity, manner is
temporally simultaneous with direction. V1 and V2 events necessarily overlap such
that V1 occurs at all time points of V2 but V2 does not occur at all time points of V1.

Emai complex predicates identify the telic end state of a change of quantitative
state. Telicity is coded by semantically differentiated V2 forms se, gbe, khoon and so.
Each conveys, respectively, an end state that is sufficient, excessive, satisfactory or
maximal. The entire predication brings into perspective an incremental change of
quantitative state expressed by V1 and assigns to its end state a telic condition.

grammatical marking of aspect and polarity. In perfect and imperfect aspect as well
as negation, fixed tone affects the verb. Nonfixed tone characterizes the verb in
prospective aspect.

2 Morphology
Word forms in Emai arise through morphological processes of inflection and deriva-
tion. Inflection expresses number. More than other parts of speech, nominal roots
inflect for number, with prefixes attaching to noun roots, nominal pronouns and
nominal modifier roots. Verb inflection and adverb inflection each involve a single
affixal form.
     Derivation impacts verbs, nouns and adverbs. Verb derivation is limited to af-
fixation. Nominal derivation manifests three major structural types: nominalization,
compounding and reduplication. Derivation lexicalizes nouns from nouns, nouns
from verbs, nouns from verb-noun collocations, adverbs from verbs, and nouns
from entire phrases. Within each of these types there are structural subtypes based
on formal or functional criteria.

8 Be, do, happen and have
Emai employs several copula forms to articulate grammatical functions associated
with English ‘be’ as well as various verbs to convey ‘do,’ ‘happen’ and ‘have.’ Al-
though the phonological form expressing some functions of ‘be,’ ‘do,’ and ‘happen,’
respectively, are identical, their tonal behavior and grammatical properties are dis-
tinct. The form expressing ‘have’ shows no phonological similarity to either ‘be’ or
‘do’ forms. A residual set of verb forms expressing meanings related to ‘resemble’
and ‘seem’ occupy final sections of this chapter.8.1 ‘be’ forms
Emai employs five ‘be’ forms. Two allow a speaker to re-align a referent with respect
to presumed discourse knowledge of the hearer. One form specifies referent identity
for the addressee (óò), and another equates one referent to another (khi). Remaining
‘be’ forms convey predication, assigning a referent to either a nominal class (vbi/u),
property (u) or location (ri/e).(1) a. óáìn         lí í khì àgbògbòràn.
       that.one PF ID be woodpecker
       ‘That one is a woodpecker.’
    b. ìyó kí óò.
       DMD NF be
       ‘It isn't that.way.’
    c. ólí ómòhè vbì óì.
       the man         be thief
       ‘The man is a thief.’
    d. ólì èkpèn ú             nwènénwèné.
       the leopard PRP.be spotted
       ‘The leopard is spotted.’
    e. ólí óvbèkhàn ríì          vbí ìwè.
       the youth         PRP.be LOC house
       ‘The youth is in the house.’Each ‘be’ form defines a construction with distinct grammatical behavior.1 Construc-
tion properties are assessed relative to mood and polarity, verb suffixes and inflec-
tion, in addition to auxiliary, preverb and postverbal categories. Noun phrase posi-
tions associated with ‘be’ forms are assessed with regard to NP type, animacy,
syntactic shape and repositioning in discourse.

One type of synthetic compound serves to identify a referent with respect to its parti-
tive character. Members exhibit a prefix+verb+noun morphological shape. Verbs in
partitive function synthetic compounds are sometimes difficult to identify synchron-
ically. Today they occur as verbs with limited distribution or even as adverb or ad-
jective forms that we assume derived historically from verbs.7 There are six synthetic
compound classes that bear on nominal classification.
     One synthetic compound class is formed with prefix ú-/í-, a post-verb noun and
an elided form of the verb kpa ‘apportion, give equal amounts, divide’ (òjè kpá émà
ó vbì ìtásà [Oje PRP.apportion yam CL LOC bowl] ‘Oje apportioned yam into the
bowls’). kpa compound sense results from apportioning a nominal referent by iso-
lating one part of its homogeneous mass or aggregate, any portion of which, when
isolated, is materially equivalent to any other portion.8 Lexemes in this class refer to
abstractions, locations (body part and otherwise), natural kinds and artifacts.

7.7 Noncanonical construction co-occurrence
Constructions reflecting sentence affirmation, sentence negation, positive focus,
negative focus, topic, right dislocation and information question types are con-
strained in their ability to co-occur. For constructions that relate a discourse defined
position to a corresponding grammatical relation, compatibility is possible only
with distinct grammatical relations. No two constructions are compatible when
affecting the same grammatical relation.
     Sentence affirmation and sentence negation establish a baseline for assessing
construction compatibility. Of the two, sentence negation is more restricted. SA érí'
and SN ki are compatible, although érí' must precede ki (*kí érí' ólí ómóhé gbé' ófè
[SN SA the man PAP.kill rat] ‘It is not the case, indeed, that the man killed a rat’).(154) érí' kí ólí ómóhé gbé'           ófè.
      SA SN the man PAP.kill rat
      ‘Indeed, it is not the case that the man killed a rat.’Sentence affirmation is restricted with other constructions. It appears with topicali-
zation and RD but never with positive focus, negative focus or direct questions. As
shown below, SA and topicalization are compatible, provided the matrix clause
shows relative tense Anterior ke (*ólí ómòhè, érí' ó gbé' ólí ófè [the man SA he
PAP.kill the rat] ‘As for the man, indeed he killed the rat’). Also below, SA érí' fol-

kill the rat] ‘Indeed, as for the man, he killed the rat afterward’).(155) a. ólí ómòhè, érí' ó ké'           gbé ólí ófè.

11 Aspect expressing complex predicates
Emai verbs in series articulate complex predicates that profile or bring into perspec-
tive some facet of an assumed or asserted change of state or possession change.
Often, though not always, the profiled element becomes evident via comparison to a
semantically related simple predicate of change, state or possession. Although types
among the latter are fewer in number relative to change of state, the function of
aspect changing complex predicates contrasts with the function of participant
changing complex predicates in Chapter 10.
     Several event types reveal a profiled character. Among them are event temporal
contour, manner, direct or indirect control of event realization, intentional end state
as cancelled or confirmed, telic status of a quantitative, positional or existence
change of state, contact end state, forcible dispossession, and resistance to assumed
change of possession.1 Across these broad classes, the verb inducing aspectual
change occurs as V1 or V2. In part, description of these event types reflects the ana-
lytic thrust of Talmy (2000) as well as Levin and Rappaport Hovav (2005).
     Aspect changing complex predicates manifest shapes that are transitive (NP1 V1
NP2 V2) or intransitive (NP1 V1 V2). All share an absolute constraint on linear order
of component verbs in series. In addition, they do not consistently deconstruct as
simple predications (e.g. transitives as NP1 V1 NP2 plus NP1 V2 NP2 or NP1/NP2 V2
and intransitives as NP1 V1 and NP1 V2). Immediately below are exemplars of predi-
cation types addressed in this chapter.

Locative pronouns refer to a place in situational or linguistic context. They fall into
classes based on distributional patterns.5 One class is sensitive to deictic features.
The other class manifests nondeictic, anaphoric properties.

Impersonal pronouns reflect demonstrative, kindred, quantifying and numeral clas-
ses. All but demonstrative are identical in phonological shape to corresponding
nominal postdeterminer modifiers (Chapter 4, 4.3.2). Except for numerals and uni-
versal quantifiers, impersonal pronouns inflect for number with a vowel prefix. And
all except numerals show a nondeictic, contrastive member.
     Demonstrative pronouns include deictic and nondeictic, contrastive members.
Deictic demonstrative pronouns differentiate proximal/distal through their root and
express number by vowel prefix alternation: óáìn ‘that one,’ ònà ‘this one,’ éáìn
‘those ones,’ ènà ‘these ones.’ Their root forms are identical in phonological shape
to demonstrative postdeterminer modifiers, i.e. áìn, nà. Deictic demonstrative pro-
nouns reject all modifier types. A nondeictic, contrastive demonstrative pronoun
also conveys number by vowel prefix alternation: ónóì ‘next one,’ énóì ‘next ones.’
     In contrast to other impersonal pronouns, demonstrative pronouns never occur
as head of a partitive vbi phrase (*óáín/óná/ónóí vbí élí ívbèkhàn ‘that one/this
one/the next one of the youths’). Constrained by number, demonstrative pronouns
occupy noun phrase positions. They refer to participants in the situational context.(56) a. óná / óáín        wéló'       ólì òtòì.

        ‘This one / That one swept the floor.’
     b. ónóí      ló     wèlò ólì òtòì.
        next.one PRED sweep the floor
        ‘The next one will sweep the floor.’

Four interrogative pronouns occur in Emai. All but one exhibit variation in phono-
logical shape of their final vowel conditioned by the nature of the following phono-

pronouns reflect four gender distinctions: animate, inanimate, place, and amount.

8.1.5.2 Partitive ri / e
A Partitive (PAR) function distinct from EXT and LCT is expressed by predicates ri
and e: NP ri vbi o and NP e vbi o. Its construction consists of an initial noun phrase,
either of the verbs ri or e, and a vbi complement consisting of the nondeictic locative
pronoun. PAR asserts a partitive relation between a subject referent and an assumed
456 | Be, do, happen and haveplurality indexed by nondeictic locative pronoun ò. Canonical PAR constructions
restrict their grammatical shape in the fashion of Existential constructions.
     PAR constructions exhibit few properties normally associated with verbs. ri in-
flects for aspect with an irregular tone pattern and fails to allow auxiliaries and
preverbs. Regarding aspect, PAR ri permits Present perfect (right edge low tone
subject and a high low verb tone). In typical verb phrases, high low tone occurs on
auxiliaries and preverbs, not verbs. Morever, PAR ri fails to inflect for imperfect or
prospective aspect.(83) ólí ómòhè ríì     vbì ò.
     the man PRP.be LOC them
     ‘The man is among them.’PAR e constructions never show aspect in the affirmative. They fail to inflect for
perfect, imperfect or prospective aspect.(84) a. *ólí ómóhé ló      è vbì ò.
         the man PRED be LOC them
         ‘The man will be among them.’
     b. *ólí ómóhé ó ò è vbì ò.
         the man SC H be LOC them
         ‘The man was among them.’     PAR constructions, regardless of ri or e as predicate, do not accept any auxilia-
ries or preverbs, as suggested by unacceptable epistemic Certaintive ma, relative
tense kpe, aspectualizer preverb Repetitive che and evaluative preverb kuku, among
others (*ólí ómóhé má' / kpé' / ché' / kú'kù rì vbì ò [the man PAP.CER SUB REP EVAL
be LOC them] ‘The man surely / yet / again / after all was among them’).
     In PAR constructions polarity and mood are limited. ri constructions occur as
polar interrogatives (ólí ómòhè ríì vbì ò? [the man PRP.be LOC them] ‘Is the man
among them?’) but never as negatives (*ólí ómòhè í ì rì vbì ò [the man SC NEG be LOC
them] ‘The man was not among them’) or as imperatives or prohibitives.
     PAR e constructions require Perfect Negation. In addition, they appear as polar
interrogatives but never as imperatives or prohibitives.(85) a. ómòhè í ì       è vbì ò.
        male SC NEG be LOC them
        ‘A male was not among them.’
     b. ómòhè í ì       è vbì ò?
        male SC NEG be LOC them
        ‘Wasn’t a male among them?’

tioning in discourse. ri and e constructions behave dissimilarly as well. With ri, PAR

constructions, PAR subject never corresponds to a constituent in focus, topic or
question word position. Similarly restricted are vbi complements, which fail to cor-

3.2.1.1 Phasal che, gbo, se, ghe
Phasal aspectualizers constrain auxiliary categories, sentence mood and polarity.
They also constrain one another, particularly with respect to linear order. Repetitive
(REP) che ‘again’ brings an event, including its participants, into perspective and
asserts event repetition over an interval on the time axis.

al event occurrence over a time expanse. Re-occurrence denoted by gbo is not lim-
ited by participant identity or temporal immediacy, as it is with Repetitive che.(53) ólí ómóhé gbó'        é ólí émàè.
     the man PAP.ADD eat the food
     ‘The man also ate the food / ate the food too.’Durative (DUR) se ‘still, continue, keep on’ profiles an event subphase and asserts
phasal duration relative to a definite point on the time axis. It often carries an impli-
cation that the speaker expected some other event to intervene or take its place.(54) ólí ómòhè séè          é vbí ólí émàè.
     the man PRP.DUR eat LOC the food

proximity of phasal onset or endpoint, depending on aspect, to time of utterance or
some other temporal reference point.(55) a. ólí ómóhé ghé'        híán ólí óràn.

émàè [the man PRP.DUR ADD eat LOC the food] ‘The man still ate from the food too’)
or Punctual ghe (ólí ómóhé sé' ghè khóó à [the man PAP.DUR PCT bathe CS] ‘The

few restrictions regarding aspectual inflection, modality and relative tense. Phasal
preverbs tend to occur with each aspect. Repetitive che allows Past perfect (ólí
ómóhé ché' é émàè [the man PAP.REP eat food] ‘The man again ate food’), Present
perfect (ólí ómòhè chéè é émàè [the man PRP.REP eat food] ‘The man again has eaten
food’), imperfect Continuous (ólí ómòhè ò ó ché è émàè [the man SC C REP eat food]
‘The man is eating food again’), prospective Predictive (ólí ómóhé ló chè é vbí ólí
émàè [the man PRED REP eat LOC the food] ‘The man will again eat from the food’),
and prospective Anticipative (ólí ómòhè ló chè é émàè [the man ANTI REP eat food]
‘The man is about to eat food again’). Repetitive che fails in the Habitual.
      Additive gbo appears in Past perfect (ólí ómóhé gbó' é ólí émàè [the man
PAP.ADD eat the food] ‘The man also ate the food / ate the food too’), Present per-
fect (ólí ómòhè gbóò é ólí émàè [the man PRP.ADD ate the food] ‘The man has also
eaten the food’), imperfect Continuous (ólí ómòhè ò ó gbó è ólí émàè [the man SC C
ADD eat the food] ‘The man is also eating the food’), imperfect Habitual (ólí ómóhé ó
ò gbó nwù ìmè [the man SC H ADD take farm] ‘The man also farms’), prospective
Predictive (ólí ómóhé ló gbò é ólí émàè [the man PRED ADD eat the food] ‘The man
will also eat the food’), and Anticipative (ólí ómòhè ló gbò é ólí émàè [the man ANTI
ADD eat the food] ‘The man is about to eat the food too’).
      Durative se occurs in Present perfect (ólí ómòhè séè é vbí ólí émàè [the man
PRP.DUR eat LOC the food] ‘The man has still eaten / has continued to eat from the
food’), imperfect Continuous (ólí ómòhè ò ó sé kpè ólì ìtásà [the man SC C DUR wash
the plate] ‘The man is still washing / is continuing to wash the plate’), prospective
Anticipative (ólí ómòhè ló sè é ólí émàè [the man ANTI DUR eat the food] ‘The man is
still about to / is about to continue to eat the food’), but not Past perfect, imperfect
Habitual or prospective Predictive.
      And Punctual ghe takes Past perfect (ólí ómóhé ghé' híán ólí óràn [the man
PAP.PCT cut the wood] ‘The man just cut the wood’), imperfect Continuous (ólí
ómòhè ò ó ghé è émáé ènyáà [the man SC C PCT eat food just.now] ‘The man is just
eating food now’), prospective Anticipative (ólí ómòhè ló ghè é ólí émàè? [the man
ANTI PCT eat the food] ‘Is the man about to just eat the food?’), but not Present per-
fect, imperfect Habitual or prospective Predictive.

lowing deontic Hortative í are Repetitive che (ólí ómòhè í chè kpé ólì ìtásà [the man
HOR REP wash the plate] ‘The man should wash the plate again’), Additive gbo (ólí
ómòhè í gbò é ólí émàè [the man HOR ADD eat the food] ‘The man should eat the
food too’), Durative se (ólí ómòhè í sè é ólí émàè [the man HOR DUR eat the food]

man HOR PCT eat the food] ‘The man should just eat the food’).

ticularly true of Punctual ghe, less so of Durative se, and even less of Repetitive che
and Additive gbo. Repetitive che follows each epistemic form, with Dubitatives and
assumptive rere requiring an interrogative: (ólí ómòhè záà chè é émàè [the man

with dubitatives or assumptive judgment Concessive rere. ghe combines with ra-

ómóhé zá' ghè é ólí émàè [the man PAP.RES PCT eat the food] ‘As a result the man
just ate the food’), (ólí ómóhé má' ghè é ólí émàè [the man PAP.CER PCT eat the food]
‘The man surely just ate the food’), and (ólí ómóhé khà ghé é ólí émàè [the man
PAP.HYP PCT eat the food] ‘The man would have just eaten the food’).
     Phasal aspectualizers limit co-occurrence with relative tense auxiliaries. Forms
gbo, ghe and se tend to fail with Anterior ke or Subsequent kpe. It is only che that
follows each relative tense form. It requires an interrogative structure with Anterior
ke (ólí ómòhè kéè chè é émàè? [the man PRP.ANT REP eat food] ‘Did the man eat food
again anymore?’), but not with kpe (ólí ómóhé kpé' chè é émàè [the man PAP.SUB
REP eat food] ‘The man yet ate food again’).
     As a subclass, phasal forms minimally restrict sentence mood and polarity. che,
gbo, se and ghe appear in imperative constructions: (chè é vbí ólí émàè [REP eat LOC
the food] ‘Eat from the food again’), (gbò é vbí ólí émàè [ADD eat LOC the food] ‘Eat
from the food too’), (sè é ólí émàè [DUR eat the food] ‘Continue eating the food’), and
(ghè é ólí émàè léé [PCT eat the food TEMP] ‘Just eat up all the food / Just finish eat-
ing the food’).
     Neither Additive gbo nor Punctual ghe occur in prohibitives. Both Repetitive che
and Durative se do: (é è chè é vbí ólí émàè [you PR REP eat LOC the food] ‘Don't eat
from the food again’), and (é è sè é ólí émàè [you PR DUR eat the food] ‘Don't con-
tinue eating the food’).
     Each phasal aspectualizer appears in polar questions: (ólí ómóhé ché' é émàè?
[the man PAP.REP eat food] ‘Did the man eat food again?’), (ólí ómòhè chéè é émàè?
[the man PRP.REP eat food] ‘Has the man eaten food again?’), (ólí ómóhé gbó' é vbí
ólí émàè? [the man PAP.ADD eat LOC the food] ‘Did the man eat from the food too?’),
(ólí ómòhè gbóò è vbí ólí émàè? [the man PRP.ADD eat LOC the food] ‘Has the man
eaten from the food too?’), (ólí ómòhè séè é ólí émàè? [the man PRP.DUR eat the
food] ‘Did the man continue eating the food?’), and (ólí ómòhè ò ó ghé è émáé ènyáà?
[the man SC C PCT eat food just.now] ‘Is the man just eating food now?’).
     All but Punctual ghe occur with Perfect Negation: (ólí ómòhè í ì ché è vbí ólí
émàè [the man SC NEG REP eat LOC the food] ‘The man didn’t eat from the food
again’), (ólí ómòhè í ì gbó è ólí émàè [the man SC NEG ADD eat the food [‘The man

the food] ‘The man didn’t continue eating the food’).
122 | Inflection, auxiliaries and preverbs3.2.1.2 Boundary ya, mo, òó
Boundary aspectualizers profile the temporal onset or endpoint of an event under
realis or irrealis conditions or single out the endpoint of an event as one phase of a
distal past expanse of time. Among boundary forms, òó, ya and mo express five
distinct functions. òó conveys a Conative function; ya specifies Ingressive and Past
Absolute functions; and mo articulates Egressive and a contrasting Past Absolute
function. For both ya and mo, subject phrase tone distinguishes Past Absolute from
Ingressive/Egressive.
     Conative (CON) òó ‘go to’ brings event onset into perspective and asserts a rela-
tion between subject volition/desire and event occurrence. The speaker remains
noncommittal as to event onset or completion.(56) ólí ómòhè ó ó'      è ólí émàè.
     the man SC CON eat the food
     ‘The man has gone to eat the food.’    The boundary form ya conveys Ingressive and Past Absolute functions. With
right edge low tone subject, ya with inherent low tone expresses an Ingressive (IG)
function. It brings event onset into perspective and asserts failure to achieve onset.
Ingressive ya does not arise with a right edge high tone subject.(57) a. ólí ómòhè yà       é ólí émàè.
        the man PRP.IG eat the food
        ‘The man almost started eating the food (but didn't get started).’

        the man PRP.IG break the pot CS

temporal unit we discussed.’(58) òjè yà       gbé ófé èghéènà / *òdè / *élá úkpè / *ìghéèghé.

(PA) function rendered ‘used to, formerly.’ It profiles the endpoint of an event as a

Past Absolute function.

Linear order and sentence mood constrain co-occurrence of phasal and boundary
aspectualizers. In declaratives, Conative follows each phasal preverb che, gbo, se
and ghe: (ólí ómòhè chéè ó è émàè [the man PRP.REP CON eat food] ‘The man again
went to eat food’), (ólí ómòhè gbóò ó è émàè [the man PRP.ADD CON eat food] ‘The
man also went to eat food’), (ólí ómòhè séè ó è ólí émàè [the man PRP.DUR CON eat
the food] ‘The man continued to go to eat the food’), and (ólí ómóhé ghé' ó è ólí
émàè [the man PAP.PCT CON eat the food] ‘The man just went to eat the food’).
     More restricted in distribution is Egressive mo. It follows Punctual ghe but no
other phasal preverb: (ólí ómóhé ghé' mò é ólí émàè léé [the man PAP.PCT EG eat the
food TEMP] ‘The man just almost finished eating the food’).
     Ingressive ya is unacceptable with phasal ghe and se. It precedes rather than
follows phasal che and gbo: (ólí ómòhè yà ché é vbí ólí émàè [the man PRP.IG REP eat
LOC the food] ‘The man almost ate from the food again’), and (ólí ómòhè yà gbò é vbí
ólí émàè [the man PRP.IG ADD eat LOC the food] ‘The man almost ate from the food
too’).

And Past Absolute mo fails with all phasal preverbs: (ólí ómóhé yà sé gbé ófé élá
úkpè [the man PAP.PA DUR kill rat TP year] ‘The man used to still kill rats during the
year we discussed’).
     Phasal and boundary forms combine differently in imperatives. Conative pre-
cedes or follows Durative se. It does not co-occur with other phasal forms in impera-
tives, regardless of linear order: (sè ó è émàè [DUR CON eat food] ‘Continue going to
eat food’), and (òó sè é émàè [CON DUR eat food] ‘Go to eat food meanwhile’).
     In imperatives, Ingressive ya does not occur with Repetitive che or Additive gbo.
However, it precedes Durative se and Punctual ghe: (yà sé é ólí émàè [IG DUR eat the
food] ‘Start eating the food meanwhile’), and (yà ghé é ólí émàè [IG PCT eat the food]
‘Just start eating the food’).
     Still more complex combinations of phasal and boundary aspectualizers occur.
A sampling reveals the potential for Ingressive ya to follow Conative òó and phasal
forms che, gbo, se and ghe, and for phasal se in these same structures to follow
Punctual ghe: (ólí ómòhè í yà ghé sè tón ókà é [the man HOR IG PCT DUR harvest
maize eat] ‘The man should just continue to start harvesting maize and eating it’),
(ólí ómòhè séè ó yà híán óràn [the man PRP.DUR CON IG cut wood] ‘The man contin-
ued to go to start cutting wood’), and (ólí ómòhè ghéè ó yà híán óràn [the man
PRP.PCT CON IG cut wood] ‘The man just went to start cutting wood’).

3.2.7 Preverb co-occurrenceRelative to one another preverb classes exhibit distributional limitations.18 Aspectu-
alizer preverbs will be considered first for their potential to co-occur with exemplars
of other classes. Subsequently, the potential of remaining preverb classes will be
considered in the order evaluative, temporal, manner-demonstrative, subject attrib-
utive and quantity. Positioned relative to verb (V), preverb classes exhibit the fol-
lowing linear order:
                        ASP EVAL / TEMP MD SA Q V3.2.7.1 Aspectualizers with other preverbs
Aspectualizers belonging to subclasses phasal and boundary reveal distinct pat-
terns of co-occurrence and order vis-à-vis other preverbs. Phasal preverbs (che, gbo,
se, ghe) combine with exemplars of the other five preverb classes. Relative to evalu-

ASP EVAL TEMP MD SA Q3.2.8.1 Preverb repetition
Two Emai preverbs frame one emphatic type. In nonemphatic constructions, either
Additive gbo ‘also/too’ or distal manner-demonstrative ìyó ‘that way’ precede an
otherwise unmodified verb, or a subject attributive or quantity class preverb. In
emphatic frames, gbo or ìyó precedes not only the preverb but also the verb. Em-
phatic iteration never extends to the more event-directed preverb classes aspectual-
izer and evaluative. In complex emphatic structures, gbo tends to precede the verb
and each preverb in the preverbal sequence, or it precedes only selected preverbs.
                                                             Preverb categories | 1613.2.8.2 Distribution of emphatic ìyó
Distal ìyó ‘that way’ occurs in nonemphatic constructions with verb forms as well as
preverbs for quantity, subject attributive, temporal, evaluative or aspectualizer.19
ìyó's position relative to preverb classes is split. It precedes the verb in the absence
of other preverbs. It follows (but never precedes) the classes aspectualizer (gbo),
evaluative (duu) and temporal (kpao). Relative to subject attributive (dégbe, dábo)
and quantity (dobo), ìyó precedes each but never follows either.
     In emphatic constructions, ìyó appears only with the quantity and subject at-
tributive classes. It precedes Emphatic dobo of the quantity class, and it precedes
the verb. In emphatics, ìyó never occurs between the Emphatic Reflexive and the
verb unless it also precedes the Emphatic Reflexive.(103) ólí ómóhé íyó'        dóbó óì íyó' híán ólí óràn.
      the man PAP.DMD REFL him DMD cut the wood
      ‘The man that way by himself cut the wood.’Also in emphatic constructions, ìyó precedes subjective attributives. It precedes
dégbe as well as the verb. Likewise, it precedes both dábo and its verb. No remain-
ing preverb class, aspectualizer, evaluative or temporal, appears in emphatic frames
with ìyó.(104) a. ólí ómóhé íyó'        dé'gbè íyó' híán ólí óràn.
         the man PAP.DMD carefully DMD cut the wood
         ‘The man that way carefully cut the wood.’
      b. ólí ómóhé íyó'        dá'bò        íyó' nwú óì fí à.
         the man PAP.DMD deliberately DMD take it propel CS
         ‘The man that way deliberately tossed it away.’Emphatic ìyó constructions affect only the classes subject attributive and quantity:                  ASP / EVAL / TEMP ìyó SA / Q ìyó                  V3.2.8.3 Distribution of emphatic gbo
