preverb classes. Nonemphatic gbo occurs with verbs as well as quantity, subject
attributive, temporal, and aspectualizer forms. In nonemphatic frames, where no
other preverb is present, gbo precedes the initial verb. It also precedes classes tem-
poral, subject attributive, quantity and manner-demonstrative. gbo thus precedes
each class, except evaluative.

5.8 Relative pronouns
Relative pronouns serve as head of unmarked relative clauses. ébé'/ébí', émé'/émí'
and ólì/élì occupy head position preceding a relative clause complement. No pro-
nominally headed relative clause shows Relator li, as lexically headed relative
clauses do (Chapter 4, 4.3.3.3). Pronominally headed relative clauses are con-
strained by subcategorization type. Only ólì/élì relatives occur across positions de-
fined by basic grammatical relations.5.8.1 ólì / élì relative clausesRelative pronoun ólì/élì occurs as relative clause head. It shows a number contrast
through initial vowel alternation [o ~ e]. Its final vowel elides, as does that of the
definite article with which it is formally identical (Chapter 4, 4.3.1). The pronoun
ólì/élì agrees in number with a corresponding anaphor in the relative clause: singu-
lar ólí with singular nominative pronoun ó and plural élì with plural nominative
pronoun é.(79) a. ólí ó nwú'        émà lí    òjè, ò fí        áwá údò.
         one he PAP.take yam APP Oje he PRP.hit dog stone
         ‘As for the one who gave yam to Oje, he hit a dog with a stone.’
     b. élí é       nwú'    émà lí    òjè, é     fí'     áwá údò.
        ones they PAP.take yam APP Oje they PAP.hit dog stone
         ‘The ones who gave Oje yam, they hit a dog with a stone.’Relatives signaled by ólì/élì exhibit contrasting reference patterns. Specific refer-
ence is the usual condition, as indicated in the preceding example. Generic refer-
ence, e.g. ‘whoever’ translation, requires Recurrent preverb a in the relative clause.
Singular ólì participates in such constructions, especially when the relative clause
constituent occurs in topic position, whereas élì does not (*élí é á' nwú émà lí òjè, é
fí' ólí áwá údò [ones they PAP.RC take yam APP Oje they PAP.hit the dog stone]
‘Whoever gave yam to Oje, they hit the dog with a stone’).(80) ólí ó á'       nwú émà lí       òjè, ò fí        ólí áwá údò.

     ‘Whoever gave yam to Oje, he hit the dog with a stone.’

Emai noun phrases show two conjunction types. The Comitative morpheme bíì con-
joins noun phrases. It induces high tone lowering at the left edge of its following
constituent, provided a high high sequence exists, and its final vowel elides. On the
other hand, Correlative conjunction khi precedes each correlated noun phrase.9 Its
final vowel elides and it induces high tone spread in its immediately following noun
phrase as well as high tone lowering at the left edge of each correlated noun phrase.(105) a. éwè bíì      óókhò vá'ré.
         goat COM chicken PAP.come
         ‘A goat and a chicken came.’
      b. khì     éwé khì     óókhó, yán à ò          vbí ìwè.
         CORC goat CORC chicken they H enter LOC house
         ‘As for the goat and chicken, they enter the house.’5.9.1 Comitative conjunction bíìComitative (COM) bíì restricts the grammatical properties of conjoined noun

number, animacy, syntactic shape, case and discourse features, while pronominally
headed noun phrases are even more restricted.

úkpùn ‘the woman and the cloth’).

Pre-bíì position employs a plural pronoun reflecting the bíì phrase grammatical
relation, although English translation retains a singular or plural interpretation.
Post-bíì position employs an accusative pronoun, irrespective of bíì phrase gram-
matical relation.

     There are additional restrictions on bíì phrases in focus or topic position. In fo-
cus position preceding li/ni, a pre-bíì pronominal must assume an emphatic shape
(màmàì / vbàvbà / ìyàìn bíì òjè ‘we / you / they with Oje’), though not necessarily
plural shape (mèmè / wèwè / ìyòìn bíì òjè ‘I / you / he with Oje’). In contrast, a post-
bíì pronominal in a focus position is constrained. It accepts no accusative pronouns
across first, second or third person singular (*òjè bíì mè / è / óì ‘Oje and me / you /
him’) or plural (*òjè bíì màì / vbà / íyàìn ‘Oje with us / you / them’).
     Conjoined bíì phrases in topic position are more constrained. When a bíì phrase
occurs as topic, a pre-bíì pronominal with emphatic shape is disallowed (*ìyàìn bíì
òjè ‘he and Oje’). Likewise, a bíì phrase in topic position disallows a post-bíì pro-
noun, even if it assumes accusative shape (*òjè bíì mè ‘Oje and me’).

3 Inflection, auxiliaries and preverbs
Emai inflection, auxiliary and preverb categories follow the grammatical subject
phrase and precede the initial verb of the predicate phrase. Inflection consists of
affirmative and negative aspect categories. They precede the auxiliary categories of
modality and relative tense, in that order. Preverbs follow auxiliaries.

3.2.8 Preverb order and emphatic constructionsAdditional support for order relations among preverb classes is discernable in em-
phatic constructions, which characterize narrative discourse. Aspectualizer gbo and
manner-demonstrative ìyó frame an order schema. Preverb distribution in these
constructions reflects a scale. One end has the more event-directed classes aspectu-
alizer (ASP), evaluative (EVAL) and temporal (TEMP); the other end has the partici-
pant-directed quantity (Q) class. Between are subject attributive (SA) and manner-
demonstrative (MD). Using this scale, preverbs more event-directed, e.g. aspectual-
izers, precede those more participant-directed, e.g. quantity.

Emai exhibits lexical items that reflect contact with various ethnic groups and their
languages in the relatively recent past. As well, some of these lexemes might reflect
a common historical past. For the moment, we do not pursue this historical matter.
Borrowed lexemes derive from English, Yoruba, Hausa and Igbo, among other lan-
guages. Most borrowed forms are nouns for concrete or highly abstract objects.
Verbs tend not to be borrowed.
    Lexemes that appear borrowed from English denote artifacts, food, locations
and abstractions. Many refer to referents from an English colonial era that persisted
from the 1890s to the 1960s.
